item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Electrochemically‐Driven Organocatalytic Enantioselective Oxidative Coupling of Tetrahydroisoquinolines and Acrylaldehyde
item.dc:description: Abstract An electrochemically‐driven organocatalytic enantioselective oxidative coupling of tetrahydroisoquinolines and acrylaldehyde was developed. Various chiral C1‐alkenyl tetrahydroisoquinolines derivatives were obtained with 69–86% yields and 93:7–96:4 er. Notable features of this reaction include asymmetric organocatalysis (5.0 mol% β‐ICD as catalyst), electricity as the oxidant, air atmosphere, and undivided cell. This synthetic route offers access to various optically active C1‐substituted tetrahydroisoquinolines derivatives.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

An electrochemically-driven organocatalytic enantioselective oxidative coupling of tetrahydroisoquinolines and acrylaldehyde was developed. Various chiral C1-alkenyl tetrahydroisoquinolines derivatives were obtained with 69–86% yields and 93:7–96:4 er. Notable features of this reaction include asymmetric organocatalysis (5.0 mol% β-ICD as catalyst), electricity as the oxidant, air atmosphere, and undivided cell. This synthetic route offers access to various optically active C1-substituted tetrahydroisoquinolines derivatives.
item.dc:creator: Qi‐Ying Zhang, Lu‐Xin Li, Song‐Lin Wang, Jing Ma, Hai‐Ming Guo
item.dc:title: Electrochemically‐Driven Organocatalytic Enantioselective Oxidative Coupling of Tetrahydroisoquinolines and Acrylaldehyde

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Organocatalytic Vinylogous Michael Addition/Cyclization Cascade of 2‐Alkylidene Indane‐1,3‐diones with Enals: A Regio‐ and Stereocontrolled Diversity‐Oriented Route to Indane‐1,3‐dione Derivatives
item.dc:description: Abstract A substrate‐dependent, regio‐ and stereocontrolled diversity‐oriented organocatalytic vinylogous Michael addition/cyclization cascade of 2‐alkylidene indane‐1,3‐diones with enals, using secondary amines as the catalyst, has been developed. This allows the synthesis of spiroindane‐1,3‐diones, tetrahydrofluoren‐9‐one derivatives, and benzofused oxabicyclo[3.3.1]nonanes in a highly selective manner. Plausible catalytic pathways for the formation of these biologically interesting compounds were proposed. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations have clarified and supported the mechanisms how the organocatalyst is able to activate the enals and 2‐hydroxycinnamaldehydes, directing the C−C bond forming with the vinylogous dienolates and enabling the synthesis of these interesting indane‐1,3‐diones derivatives.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

A substrate-dependent, regio- and stereocontrolled diversity-oriented organocatalytic vinylogous Michael addition/cyclization cascade of 2-alkylidene indane-1,3-diones with enals, using secondary amines as the catalyst, has been developed. This allows the synthesis of spiroindane-1,3-diones, tetrahydrofluoren-9-one derivatives, and benzofused oxabicyclo[3.3.1]nonanes in a highly selective manner. Plausible catalytic pathways for the formation of these biologically interesting compounds were proposed. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations have clarified and supported the mechanisms how the organocatalyst is able to activate the enals and 2-hydroxycinnamaldehydes, directing the C−C bond forming with the vinylogous dienolates and enabling the synthesis of these interesting indane-1,3-diones derivatives.
item.dc:creator: Jen‐Yu Kuan, I‐Ting Chen, Hsuan Lin, Jeng‐Liang Han
item.dc:title: Organocatalytic Vinylogous Michael Addition/Cyclization Cascade of 2‐Alkylidene Indane‐1,3‐diones with Enals: A Regio‐ and Stereocontrolled Diversity‐Oriented Route to Indane‐1,3‐dione Derivatives

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Selective Catalysts for the Homogeneous Semi‐Hydrogenation
item.dc:description: An efficient and highly selective semi‐hydrogenation of terminal alkynes to alkenes using neutral dimeric rhodium(I) complexes of the type [Rh(μ‐Cl)(PP)]2 is presented. Dehydroisophytol (DIP) was chosen as the alkyne for this study because of its high importance in the industrial production of synthetic vitamin E. Excellent selectivity of over 91% towards the alkene was achieved with known and new rhodium catalysts. No deactivation was observed for the [Rh(μ‐Cl)(PP)]2 complexes and the molar Rh:DIP ratio could be increased to 1:20 000, and importantly, no reduction in selectivity was observed. The results presented open the door to the industrial application of homogeneous rhodium complexes in the semihydrogenation of terminal alkynes.
item.content:encoded: An efficient and highly selective semi-hydrogenation of terminal alkynes to alkenes using neutral dimeric rhodium(I) complexes of the type [Rh(μ-Cl)(PP)]2 is presented. Dehydroisophytol (DIP) was chosen as the alkyne for this study because of its high importance in the industrial production of synthetic vitamin E. Excellent selectivity of over 91% towards the alkene was achieved with known and new rhodium catalysts. No deactivation was observed for the [Rh(μ-Cl)(PP)]2 complexes and the molar Rh:DIP ratio could be increased to 1:20 000, and importantly, no reduction in selectivity was observed. The results presented open the door to the industrial application of homogeneous rhodium complexes in the semihydrogenation of terminal alkynes.

item.dc:title: Selective Catalysts for the Homogeneous Semi‐Hydrogenation
